iceApproaches.title: If ICE Approaches You:
items: You have the right to remain silent.
You do not have to answer questions about your immigration status, where you were born, or your citizenship.
You do not have to show documents unless you are driving a vehicle
and legally required to show your license and registration.
You have the right to refuse searches.
You do not have to consent to a search of yourself, your belongings, or your home without a warrant.
Request an attorney.
You have the right to speak with a lawyer before answering questions.
Do not sign anything.
Never sign documents from ICE without consulting a lawyer.
If detained, you have the right to make a phone call
to a lawyer or trusted contact.

emergencyContacts.title: Emergency Contacts:
items: Legal aid Hotlines: Keep the phone numbers for reliable immigration legal aid organizations handy. They can explain your rights, connect you with attorneys, and guide you through ICE encounters.

Rapid Response Networks: Identify local immigrant or rapid-response groups that can assist if someone is detained. They may provide on-the-ground support, advocacy, and connections to bail or legal resources.
Trusted Contacts: Make sure at least one friend, family member, or trusted person knows your location and can check in if needed.
emergencyContacts.top: Keeping important contacts accessible can help you and your loved ones stay safe in unexpected situations.
emergencyContacts.bottom: Store these numbers in your phone, in a wallet, or on a ‚ÄúKnow Your Rights‚Äù card. Consider keeping a small paper list as backup in case your phone is lost or confiscated.

footer.disclaimer: This is a community-driven tool for safety awareness. Report information responsibly and verify alerts when possible.
footer.emergency: For immediate emergencies, contact local emergency services. For immigration legal help, contact qualified legal aid organizations.

resources.title: Resources
resources.subtitle: Here are some helpful resources to know your rights and find legal assistance.
resources.resourceSection1: Steps to Take if a Loved One is Detained

resource1.title: Find Legal Help Near You
resource1.description: Search the National Immigration Legal Services Directory to locate free or low-cost legal aid organizations across the U.S., and quickly connect with trusted resources in your area.

resource2.title: Carry Your Rights With You
resource2.description: This wallet-sized Know Your Rights card, created by the Immigrant Legal Resource Center (ILRC), helps you assert your rights during encounters with ICE or law enforcement. Available in multiple languages, it's easy to print, carry, and show when needed.

resource3.title: We Have Rights‚Äì Emergency Plan and Resources
resource3.description: Prepare yourself and your loved ones with the We Have Rights Emergency Plan, a free publicly available guide from Brooklyn Defender Services. It provides step-by-step instructions for ICE encounters and includes links to videos and additional legal resources. Available in English, Spanish, and other languages for easy access and printing.
